work.p: This manuscript contains an early draft of "I Saw in Louisiana a Live-Oak Growing" first published as No. 20 of the "Calamus" cluster in the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass.

titleStmt.title: growing
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably composed between 1856 and 1860.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: [I Saw in Louisiana a Live Oak Growing] Holograph of five lines of the poem.
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature
bibl.note: Transcribed from our own digital image of original manuscript.

l.seg: All alone stood it, and the moss
And its look, rude, unbending, lusty,
But I wondered how it could
lover—For I know knew I could
And I plucked a twig with a certain
number of leaves upon it and
twined around it a little moss,
have placed it in sight in my

div1.head: Poems
div1.p: Fit to be perused during the days of the approach of Death.
(that I have prepared myself for that purpose.—
